p.s: The sonnet engages with the theme of how two people lie in a relationship to surpass each otherseach other's insecurities, againg and not being made of truth.
In the following, it will be outlined how the autherauthor illustrates and intensifies his view by means of formal and poetic devices.
The poem is a fourteen lined sonnet which can be devideddivided into three quatrains and one heroic couplet.
The sonnet is written in an iambic pentameter and conforms to the rhyme pattern abab cdcd efef gg.
The iambic pentameter illustrates a heartbeat created by five stressed and five unstressed syllables.
The heartbeat embraces the theme of love which is presented in the sonnet.
ShakespearShakespeare conforms to a constant rymerhyme scheme.
The three quatrains follow a cross pattern and the couplet a pair rhyme scheme.
The rhyme scheme is unchanged in the sonnet signifying harmony.

The pair rhyme in the heroic couplet stresses the message of the sonnet that both people in the relationship conquer the ravages in life, forming a pair which is trapped in edlessendless devotion and admiration.
ShakespearShakespeare employs a variety of poetic devices in order to highlight the speaker's strong devotion towards his lover.
In line fiveShakespeare invokes an alliteration vainly thinking that she thinks me young (l. 5).
The alliteration highlights the speakersspeaker's fear of old age.
Moreover, the passage stresses the speakersspeaker's high admiration towards the lover, sincec only his/her opinion really matters.
Furthermore, ShakespearShakespeare implies a personification proclaiming he simply credits her false speaking tongue (l. 7).
By employing a personificationShakespeareemphazisesemphasizes that the speaker feels flattered by the lovers lies.
It visulizesvisualizes that the lover helps the speaker overcome his insecurities by lying.
He relies on the lover lying, helping him to not anguish by the fact he's aging.
Another stylistic device can be found in line nine to ten.
The author employs two rhetorical questions signifying why the speaker and loved person do not proclaim each otherseach other's flaws.
Wherefore says she not she is unjust(l. 9), wherefore say not that I am old?.
The questions characterizescharacterize the seeming trust in a realationshiprelationship.
Knowing that no one will point out the othersother's flaws.
Moreover, ShakespearShakespeare invokes another alliteration age in love loves not have years told (l. 12) highlighting, love does not want to be told how many years it has left.
Love is pictured as something immortal.
Love is worth of not always telling the truth, in order to not hurt the other beloved person.
All in all, ShakespearShakespeare illustrates the strong bond between the speaker and his/her beloved person by highlighting lifeslife's brevity and fading ages.
Little flaws are not worth pointed out because life is too short to be arguing the whole time.
Furthermore, the form of the poem stresses the harmony between the two people, loving each other and overcoming the ravages of life and love.
